G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord “shall not directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.”

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, because this is an action concerning residential housing, a landlord-tenant relationship, and claims related to the use and occupancy of a residential dwelling.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Division of the Housing Court Department under G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3, 6 because the Premises are located in Jamaica Plain, Massachusetts, within this Division, and the acts and omissions complained of occurred there.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The recurring water intrusion and resulting conditions are not merely aesthetic; they implicate basic habitability, health, and safety, and are violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to provisions requiring the owner to maintain the structure and building elements in good repair and free from chronic dampness and mold.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a non‑delegable duty to maintain the roof, structure, and building systems serving the Apartment in a condition that would not result in recurrent water intrusion or unsanitary conditions.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: An award of Plaintiff’s costs of this action and, to the extent permitted by G.L. c. 186, § 14, reasonable attorney’s fees, together with interest as allowed by law pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this statutory covenant is construed broadly to protect tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or neglect.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case clearly holds that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when substantial interference with the tenancy is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, even absent intent, and where the landlord has the right to control the objectionable condition. That reflects a relatively broad, protective construction of the covenant against substantial interferences tied to the landlord’s acts or neglect. However, the opinion speaks in common-law terms (“implied covenant”) and does not expressly construe a particular statutory covenant, so tying it specifically to “this statutory covenant” is somewhat imprecise.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this statutory covenant is construed broadly to protect tenants from substantial interference with their tenancy caused by the landlord’s acts or neglect.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and explains that it is not limited to intentional conduct but extends at least to reckless interference. The court roots its reading in the common-law understanding of “quiet enjoyment” as protecting tenants from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises, and emphasizes that the tenant-protection statutory scheme addresses harms from unsanitary conditions regardless of the landlord’s specific intent. This is a broad, tenant-protective construction consistent with the stated proposition.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ — words that have little inherent meaning but a rich background in decisional law — it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute…. [T]he statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.”

*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: In *Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), the Court held that proof of a willful or knowing interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 entitles the tenant to actual and consequential damages, or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and that landlord neglect of serious conditions after notice can constitute such interference.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion does reaffirm that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires at least negligent conduct by a landlord and that failure to repair known defects can violate § 14, so the second half of the proposition (about landlord neglect after notice) is generally consistent with the Court’s discussion. However, this case does not state or decide that proof of a willful or knowing interference entitles the tenant to actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater; that remedial formula is set out in the text of § 14 and in other cases, not in this opinion. Here, the Court’s focus is narrowly on whether a strict-liability lead paint violation automatically constitutes a § 14 violation and on the mental state (at least negligence) required, not on the measure of damages under § 14.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy serious or recurring defective conditions within the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion recites that the trial judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on the deplorable, recurring conditions in the apartment (heat problems, infestations, and other serious defects) that Cruz Management failed to correct despite notice. Although the Supreme Judicial Court does not analyze § 14 in detail because damages would have been duplicative, it leaves that finding undisturbed and cites Simon v. Solomon for the principle that such conditions can support quiet enjoyment liability. Thus the case implicitly affirms that a landlord’s failure to remedy serious, ongoing defects after notice can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The judge rendered a written decision in Wideman’s favor concluding, among other things, that conditions in her apartment had been in breach of the implied warranty of habitability… During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). Cruz Management had notice of these defects, as well as others… Most of the violations remained uncorrected through October, 1990… Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award.

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Leaks, chronic dampness, and related unsanitary or unhealthy conditions have been held to interfere substantially with a tenant’s use of the premises and to support claims for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but only in the context of criminal drug activity and lack of security measures in common areas. It does not address leaks, chronic dampness, or unsanitary/ unhealthy physical conditions, nor does it hold that such conditions constitute a substantial interference supporting a quiet enjoyment claim. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. ... In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises."

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Leaks, chronic dampness, and related unsanitary or unhealthy conditions have been held to interfere substantially with a tenant’s use of the premises and to support claims for breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals specifically with a landlord’s failure to provide heat and holds that such failure constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It does not address leaks, chronic dampness, or related unsanitary or unhealthy conditions. While it supports the broader idea that serious habitability defects (here, lack of heat) can substantially interfere with a tenant’s use and quiet enjoyment, it is not authority for the specific proposition about leaks and dampness.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ (Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 [1929], quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]), and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Violations of these regulations may constitute evidence of a substantial interference with quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly ties State Sanitary Code violations (including failure to supply adequate heat and hot water) to habitability and to the tenant’s rent-abatement remedy. The court states that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable and that such noncompliance cannot be waived, thereby confirming that violations of these regulations are evidence of a substantial interference with the tenant’s interest in habitable, quiet enjoyment of the premises. The reasoning thus supports using regulatory violations as evidence of substantial interference with quiet enjoyment/habitability.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. … Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice.”

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant had a non‑delegable duty to maintain the roof, structure, and building systems serving the Apartment in a condition that would not result in recurrent water intrusion or unsanitary conditions.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The concurrence rejects the old caveat emptor rule and expressly states that statutes and the State Sanitary Code impose on landlords, for the benefit of tenants, an obligation to comply with minimum standards of fitness, including safe and sanitary conditions. It further says that by renting, the landlord impliedly agrees both that the unit complies at inception and that he will do whatever the law requires during the term to maintain that compliance. While it does not single out roofs or building systems by name, the reasoning clearly embraces a non‑delegable, ongoing duty to maintain structural and sanitary conditions consistent with the Code.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tentant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Defendant’s conduct likewise constitutes a “direct or indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, because Defendant failed to act reasonably to correct conditions that he knew, or had reason to know, were substantially interfering with Plaintiff’s use of the Premises.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known conditions that substantially impair the value of the premises constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14. It emphasizes that omissions such as failure to repair defects after notice are actionable under § 14 and that the landlord’s conduct, not intent, controls. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s failure to act reasonably to correct known, substantially interfering conditions is a “direct or indirect interference” with quiet enjoyment under the statute.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. See Simon v. Solomon… (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko… (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas… (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and to keep it so). A ‘landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716, on the question whether there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s conduct likewise constitutes a “direct or indirect interference” with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, because Defendant failed to act reasonably to correct conditions that he knew, or had reason to know, were substantially interfering with Plaintiff’s use of the Premises.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion never discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, ‘quiet enjoyment,’ or ‘direct or indirect interference’ with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment. The decision addresses sanitary code obligations, security deposits, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability, and c. 93A, but not a landlord’s liability for failing to reasonably correct known conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition asserted.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
